awd_titl_txt: Manipulating photon-atom interactions with atomic coherence and interference
awd_abstract_narration:
This experimental research program studies atomic coherence and interference induced by coherent interactions between laser fields and multi-level atomic systems, and explore its applications in nonlinear optics and quantum optics. Two experimental approaches will be developed and used in the research program. In the first approach, quantum state manipulation and control of atoms and photons with cold atoms confined in an optical cavity will be explored. The cavity enhanced nonlinear wave mixing in coherently driven cold atoms and slow light propagation assisted by the intra-cavity dark state will be studied. The atoms-cavity system will also be used to study photon switching and photon correlations. In the second approach, quantum nonlinear optics will be studied with cold atoms in free space. Two-channel four-wave mixing will be studied and used to explore generation of entangled and correlated photon pairs. Large Kerr nonlinearities and cross-phase modulation manifested by electromagnetically induced transparency will be investigated. Also the multi-photon quantum interference in coherently prepared three-level and four-level systems will be studied and used to explore applications of light control light by manipulating the amplitude and phase of a weak control field.  

These experimental studies will lead to discoveries of new phenomena and contribute to the advancement of fundamental quantum optics and nonlinear optics at ultra-low light intensities. It will also lead to the development of new techniques to control the quantum states of atoms and photons, which will be useful for applications in quantum measurements and quantum information network.  The proposed research implements advanced experimental methods and sophisticated spectroscopic measurements, which offers research related education and training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students and enable them to develop scientific knowledge and technical skills for their pursuit of scientific careers.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum coherence and interference manifested in multi-level atomic systems has been a subject of intense studies in recent years. Such studies have contributed to the rapid progresses in nonlinear optics, quantum optics, and quantum information science, and also found practical applications in quantum electronics and photonics in recent years. With the NSF support, the PI’s research program has been actively involved in this research field. The main focus of PI’s research program has been on electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT) and its manifestation in nonlinear optical phenomena and spectroscopic measurements in cold atoms in free space or confined in a cavity.  The research objectives were to understand the fundamental physics in coherent atom-photon interactions, develop the coherent optical techniques based on the concepts of atomic coherence and interference, and explore their possible applications in laser spectroscopy and quantum optics.

  During the funding period, the PI’s research program provided learning and training opportunities for four graduate students, three postdoctoral associate, and seven undergraduate students. Among them, two graduate students and seven undergraduate students were Hispanic minority students.

  With the NSF support, the PI’s research group carried out a series of experiments that were designed to explore the basic physics in coherent atom-photon interactions in a coupled atom and cavity system and develop new methods to manipulate the quantum states of cavity QED system by the laser induced coherence and interference. During the funding period, the group obtained important scientific results from these experiments and developed theoretical models to simulate and understand the experimental results. The group’s research activities resulted in eight published papers in peer-reviewed physics journals, two conference proceedings, ten invited and two contributed papers in the national and international conferences and meetings.

   The group’s work has advanced the current understanding of the multi-atom cavity QED and atomic coherence and interference, and contributed to the fundamental knowledge of coherent atom-photon interactions. The coherently prepared multi-atom cavity QED system may be used to explore a variety of physical phenomena in quantum optics and nonlinear optics. Such studies are currently being carried out in the PI’s laboratory with continued funding from the NSF and may lead to the development of the coherent optical techniques that will be useful for practical applications in precision measurements, optics communications, and nonlinear optical devices.
